DataElement.preferredName: Other Neoplasm Germ Cell Tumor Histological Examination Identification Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The yes/no response that asks whether other germ cell tumor type was found on histologic examination.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Other Neoplasm Germ Cell Tumor Histological Examination Identification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._A benign or malignant, gonadal or extragonadal neoplasm that originates from germ cells. Representative examples include teratoma, seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, and yolk sac tumor._The procedure of having an identity established._Technique or procedure used for the study of the microanatomy of tissues and their cellular structure; usually involves microscopic examination of tissue slices.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Germ Cell Tumor Histological Procedure Identification
Property.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant, gonadal or extragonadal neoplasm that originates from germ cells. Representative examples include teratoma, seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, and yolk sac tumor.:Technique or procedure used for the study of the microanatomy of tissues and their cellular structure; usually involves microscopic examination of tissue slices.:The procedure of having an identity established.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant, gonadal or extragonadal neoplasm that originates from germ cells. Representative examples include teratoma, seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, and yolk sac tumor.
Technique or procedure used for the study of the microanatomy of tissues and their cellular structure; usually involves microscopic examination of tissue slices.
The procedure of having an identity established.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
